Ethnos  is a game I've wanted to get to the table for a long time. I finally got it to the table and I was excited of how well it turned out. The game is very simplistic. But the added mechanism of when you lay down a band of cards you have to put the rest of your hand out for somebody else to grab. The Third Dragon sneaks up on you very quickly.
Sadly my gaming group didn't care for this game which I found intriguing in its simple yet rich design.  Was not put off at all by components (as some were).

I really enjoyed Ethnos when I first played it, but as I've let it sit for a while I've really cooled on it. It's essentially Ticket to Ride with a pasted-on theme, and that's just not compelling enough to make a game great. Some people may find a lot of value in the accessibility, but the simplicity of the game makes it boring, not accessible. There's absolutely nothing to sink your teeth into here.

While the area control is rather interesting, I have plenty of other area control games that are not that much more complex, but far more satisfying than Ethnos, which is disappointingly linear and offers no way to move placed troops.

Played it yesterday with 4 players. I've got to say I'm not as enamored by it as the community appears to be. It took us 90 minutes to finish the game and I think it's slightly more than the game should take (should be as the box says: 60 minutes). Maybe it's due to halflings which essentially add 12 more cards to the deck and prolong the game. What is more, I don't think I will ever play with halflings again. They also make players focus more on set collection than area control. The former is too much based on luck, whereas area control requires more skills and I'd rather there was more emphasis on it. On top of that - at least in our game - there were often moments when players just kept on blind drawing from the top of the deck hoping for something matching their band. Sometimes a player would play a band and discard 2 or 3 cards which were gone in a second. I don't know... after that first game seems too much based on blind draw. I'd rather there were more options to more consciously draw cards. And last thing: some races are really uninteresting at certain points. Trolls' tokens were gone fast and minotaurs seem not necessary in the first 2 ages. I've got to play it again without halflings, maybe with 3 players this time?

Overall, it is a very good game that fits the bill if you don't want something too weighty. 

Regarding the seemingly constant criticisms of this game's art/design, the pictures of the board/components make its art/design seem worse than it is. There's nothing wrong with the art/design of the game in person, as it's going for a classic/timeless look. It succeeds in that regard. The quality of the art work is high (without regard to whether one enjoys the setting or not) and the design of the board/cards is clean and functional. If anything, the tokens could have been a bit more sculpted on the bottom to assist in stacking stability, and the board could have been made a bit taller along the y-axis.

An excellent gateway+ style game. It takes the familiar mechanics of set collection and area control and gives it a couple new twists. One, when you play a set you also get a special power depending on the kind of card you choose as the "leader" of the set. Each game has 6 different cards in play with a total of 12 in the box so each game will play a bit different. Also, when you play a set any unused cards get discarded to the table where your opponents now have a chance to snatch them up. This means you want to build your set efficiently but building a big set can mean big windfalls for your opponents as you will likely have some unusable cards in the end. The production quality of the game itself is subpar by CMON standards since the board is rather small and the art is generic fantasy but it's all functional. Also the turns are super quick so you're only even taking a card or playing a set. Overall excellent game.

And you really cannot do very much anything during your turn, as you either draw a card or place a set of cards in front of you on the table. If you made the latter one, then you also place some marker on the game board and discard all extra cards from your hand. So you need to start that slow card collecting process from the very beginning again, if you were not lucky to play a race that saves your cards in your hand.

Maybe this game would make more sense to play with less than 6 players. It would need at least some permanent market, so that players wouldn't be forced to take blind cards. However, there is too much push-your-luck for me.

This game's essence, is rummy. A wonderfully new interpretation of it, but it's still, a card drawing game. If you like waiting on lucky card draws, trying to decide when to cut your losses or whether your discards will help others, this game is for you. 

On the plus side:
*In addition to set collection, there's also an area majority mechanic that is significant. It requires ever luckier draws to get the area majorities, but it adds a risk/reward element to your decision
* Suits have powers that affect what you are trying to get
* Some suits or suit combinations mitigate or improve upon the rummy aspect
* Turns should be quick
* Replayability is high
* Expandability is high, and I'm sure they will do this

On the down side:
* Cards are very poor quality, which is a horrible thing in a card game. Add sleeves to the price if you're considering buying.
* Cards are not very well designed to see at a glance the two aspects (region/faction)
* The luck aspect is pretty significant. By the second age, you'll typically be waiting for a usable card once your hand takes shape
* Some starting suits or suit combinations work poorly and strip down the game rather than augment it
* Takes a lot longer than 3 hands of rummy, and requires some set up/tear down

Overall, this is a much-enhanced version of rummy, which I don't really enjoy. The enhancements add depth, and play time, without mitigating the weaknesses very well (although some combinations of starting factions actually work well together). As a light card game, you almost need sleeves because of the poor card quality, so it's pretty expensive for what it is. Still, there's a game here, and if this kind of card game is your thing, I could recommend you check it out even though it's not to my taste.

The push-your-luck mechanism when taking cards has some interesting dynamics, especially toward the end of the game, but ultimately is less interesting than I had hoped. The band mechanism balances that out a bit and does offer an alternative VP path, but overall it's fairly random with a predominantly tactical feel, which is fine for what it is and for its length. The key to the game seems to be to play reactively with what you are able to muster rather than trying to plan ahead too much.

Ethnos is a card game where players will play sets of cards in an effort to apply those sets to certain regions of the board, gaining majority control in each territory. What it adds are plenty of interestingly direct decisions (push luck for a larger set vs play now for majority token) that both offer interesting decision points while still offering player turns that whip around very quickly.  Here is a constant choice between a powerful ability or going for territory control for a good deal of points. Ethnos' art can be a hard sell, and it can be difficult to see what makes the game such a good time to play. This game is one of the few that play well and very quickly at all player counts, offers the same wonderful tension of ability benefit vs points benefit, and has the feel of a race to play before the deck is diminished--something Paolo Mori does very well in his designs. It scales very well and is worth playing. Regarding the art, it is commonplace to see it as a detractor, but John Howe gives a positive sense of nostalgic ties to his earlier work for Lord of the Rings. The game compares nicely to the charming Ticket to Ride, but the twists are enough to allow it to stand on its own ground. Ethnos is a great game, often sneaking itself into the play pile and leaving players unsuspectingly satisfied with the play afterwards.

I have disliked every Cool Mini or Not game I have played (with the possible exception of Xenoshyft, the jury is still out on that one) so I wasn’t expecting much from Ethnos. The reason I bought it was the designer, Paolo Mori, which I respect a lot. Every game I have played from him has had some interesting feature and Ethnos is no exception.

The rules of the game are easy to grasp and teach, you can teach them under 6 minutes. Playtime is, surprisingly, fast. Even with 6 players, there is almost no downtime.

One thing I have come to expect from CMON is the high quality of their games, but here, they dropped the ball. The board is way too small and ugly. The art of the cards is functional, but nothing special. The player´s pieces are merely ok, but they are unstable. I’m very surprised by this.

The theme is really cool, but sadly, it is pasted on. You really don’t feel it in the game.

Gameplay is very fun. At first I was very engaged with the game. You will play for 3 rounds and at the beginning here are many cards to choose from but after a couple of turns you will have to draw from the deck and luck will decide which card you will get (this bothers me a lot and it is the deal breaker for me). The decisions needed to play the game aren’t very hard making Ethnos a family level game. Either you play your hand or you draw another card. When you play your hand you will discard the cards that you didn’t play. This is a neat feature.

There are 12 races in the game and you will only use 6 in each game, each race has a different power. I love this feature in games. The relationship between the races will be different most times and it is easily expandable. It also makes the game highly repayable.

The luck factor is high. When you lose a position, there is no way to attack again if the cards don’t help. When you have options of which card to draw the game is great, but when you have to blindly draw from the deck (as most times) the game is boring.

Another issue is that the first players have a definitive advantage as the round ends immediately. This means the first players will have (more likely) more turns than everybody else. I didn’t see any way to mitigate this and I feel it is very unfair.

When you attack a player, it doesn’t really feels like an attack, that is, you don’t feel the game is mean and that’s weird in an area control game. I prefer games to be this way.

Bottom line, Ethnos is among the best CMON games I have played, but the luck factor is too much for me. I already sold my copy of the game. I would play again if requested as I kind of liked it. I´m very glad the game moves at a fast pace so the 2 big issue I have with the game can be (barely) forgotten. Perhaps with 2 players the luck factor would be reduced. The graphic design leaves a lot to be desired and that’s very weird coming from CMON. It can be a good family game or it can serve as an introductory game for new gamers. It is mostly a tactical endeavor.

At first I was struck by how similar Ethnos was to Ticket to Ride. Draft a card or play a set are your basic choices. You play sets in order to place a token in one of six regions. Sets either have to match color or race and the top card becomes the "leader". Typically, the color of the leader matches the region where your token goes. However, every race has a different ability that activates when you make them the leader. This can influence placements or points and many races have a sub-game on the side which can be another source of points. The game is divided into three eras, after each is a majority scoring by region and players score their played sets: bigger sets = more points. The deck is shuffled between eras, but tokens stay on the board, so the long play is the majority game.

In Ethnos the turns are fast, the thinking is pretty simple, but the racial abilities give you real options as to who you are going to have lead each set and why. Point values of the regions are randomly set up by era, so some regions can be valuable from the get go, some are low value until the end and some are never all that valuable. The variation of region scoring and races in play give Ethnos decent replayability. I can break this out with serious and casual gamers. I'm starting this out at a 7, but I could see this rising to an 8 with more play. If the audience for this is a broad as I suspect, it won't take long to get there.

How can a new game look so old-fashioned in 2017? Every average Kickstarter game looks far better than this release. The gory illustrations by John Howe are a huge mismatch to the drab gameboard and the otherwise functional graphics. 

Once beyond these stumbling blocks, Ethnos is a solid eurogame; a smooth mix of set collection, push-your-luck and area majority. Players try to collect sets in rummy-style. The trick is that they are allowed to collect a maximum of ten cards before having to play a set and then discarding the rest of their hand to the center display. This display is quickly emptied and not refilled from the draw stack. Thus, drawing blind and hoping for a matching card is a big part of the game. Gamble high unsuccessfully and the game can be lost early on.

With the played set, players can place one army to the board with each consecutive army in the same area being more expensive. The leader of the set played grants a special effect depending on his suit. Only six of the twelve suits are in each single game ensuring variance between plays. A good game for a higher player count if played reasonably quickly.

I like this game, but a few things keep me from being as enamored with it as I normally would be. For one thing, the theme is almost nonexistent. You're playing these fantasy races in sets to control areas of the board, but the theme could have almost been anything. Also, the little discs that you use to show control are one of my least favorite components ever. They're difficult to store properly in the insert, and they're so difficult to stack that they constantly fall apart when I handle them. Lastly, I feel like the round end scoring is a little awkward at times. In each area of the board, ties are very likely to happen, and so most of your points actually come from the sets you've made. It's fine, I guess, but a little strange in execution.

Those things aside, I did find myself enjoying Ethnos. It's a bit of a slog for an area control game that should be this simple, as you're only drawing one card every turn. It's also a little awkward that the card offer doesn't replenish unless someone has cards left in their hand after playing a set. It really made me long for the Ticket to Ride style of replenishing the offer and having the choice of drawing two cards every turn. Having to blindly draw one card from turn to turn can be really annoying.

I'm really coming off as nit-picky on Ethnos, but I don't really mean to. It was just a bit of a slow burn for me, and I imagine it will get better with repeated plays. This really does feel like the best gateway to area control out there, even if the fantasy theme may be a little off-putting for some. The area control actually isn't as interesting as the card play and their abilities, which range from really cool to just being extra ways of scoring points.

It all feels very dry and Euro-y, which is typical of Paulo Mori's games, but it is nonetheless fun. This is probably my favorite game of his along with Libertalia and Augustus, but all of them are prone to runaway leaders, which is a pretty major drawback for me. So time will tell if this game rises or falls for me, but I do think it has potential despite its rough edges.

In this area control game, there are 6 tribes (out of 12) that are in the game. There are 12 cards per tribe and 6 colors. You are either drafting  a card from the draw deck or face up on the table, or you are forming a band of cards of the same suit, which allow you to put  a control token on the map for area control scoring. The band of cards also score points for the length, with the longer the better. Your other unplayed cards go face up on the table after you band. 

The end of the round is triggered by the appearance of the third dragon card and the game last 3 rounds. 

It's a fun game, as there is tension when the second dragon card shows up, and you want to complete a band before the third dragon card ends the round. The mechanics are easy. Yes, there is luck in your initial card, and what you draw afterwards. It's fun to explore the different abilities of the tribes. We'll see how the game holds up after repeated playings, and 4 players would appear to be the sweet spot. I like the design, but certainly, the luck can be hard to overcome.

The art style is the same as you can expect from the artist who has done a lot of Lord of the Rings stuff in the past. I think it works great for the cards, but I could see it being nice if the board was more vibrant, but really the game is not as ugly as people say and still looks pretty good to me. This is just a great game that is almost a mix between abstract and thematic

規則:
*放置圖板，隨機放置分數標記在圖板對應位置，然後每個照數字小到大排列，2~3人時把有4+符號的移除，然後每個區域放兩個而已，隨機選取六個種族卡洗勻(2-3人時使用五個)
*每人拿一個顏色標記，一個放0分，如果有對應的種族卡有特殊圖板也放在特殊圖版的起始格
*遊戲進行三輪(2-3人進行兩輪)，每輪可以分成三個階段
1.設置 每人抽一張種族卡，開人數*2張，然後種族卡分成同數量的兩疊，把三張龍卡隨機洗勻在下面那疊在疊起，第一輪隨機起始，之後分數低的開始(平手靠近抽第三張龍卡的先)
2.行動 輪流行動，每次行動二選1
>抽一張牌，可抽開著的或蓋著的，不補牌，抽到龍卡放一旁在重抽，抽到第三張此輪結束
>出牌 一次出一疊同色或同圖案的，選一張放最上面可啟動能力，出的該疊放面前，張數如果比第一張顏色對應區的你的標記還多，則可以在放一個標記在該區(兩人時要比所有人標記多)，剩下的手牌全部棄到開牌區
3.結束 第三張火龍卡抽到結束，每個地區根據標記數目多少計分，只會獎勵對應輪數的前幾名(第一輪第一名)，分數從對應輪數的數字給，平手則加總分數平均向下取整(兩人時，第二輪第二名沒分，但是如果獨佔該區則拿第一跟第二格的分數總合)，面前的牌每疊1/2/3/4/5/6+張拿0/1/3/6/10/15分，所有手牌跟面前的牌棄掉在重新洗勻
*遊戲最後分數高勝利，平手比圖板上標記數，在比最後一輪的面前一疊牌張數最多的
****種族能力****
>Centaurs  如果出牌後可成功放置標記，可馬上再出一次牌並啟動新牌的領袖能力，結算完後再棄牌

>Giants 出牌時如果該疊是場上目前最多的巨人疊拿兩分(可跟自己比)，並拿巨人標記，每輪結束再拿上面分數然後返還

Ethnos is a set-collection area-majority game set in a fantasy universe. Each game will use six of the 12 possible races; cards from those races are shuffled into a large deck. Players must then collect and play cards either all of the same race or all of the same color to place a token in a region--the number of cards in the set must exceed the number of tokens you already have in that region. The card on top of the played set determines the color of the region you place in, and its race determines the special ability you get when you play the set. At the end of each of the three rounds, players score majorities for regions, as well as triangular points for the size of their sets. This game was very easy to learn and play. However, as a card game it had a significant random factor, and lacked some of the strategic depth I would like.

This is an area majorities flip luck heavy game that genuinely manages to be compelling, which is an unusual thing for me to encounter. The idea is this; the central board has different regions that do a majority scoring each round. On your turn you draw one card from either the faceup display or the top of the facedown deck, or you play one or more cards that either all have the same color, or have the same fantasy race, and then you discard the rest of your unplayed hand to the display for other players to pick over. If the cards you played were greater than the number of tokens you have in the region of matching color, you get to add one new token. You also get to use the special power of the top card in the set played, and this is where the game gets really interesting. Despite how luck of the draw it is, you actually wind up with interesting puzzles in your hand as you have to choose what you want to go for, faction ability, color, and which province you are aiming for. Then you also have an aspect of pushing your luck, knowing that each time you blind draw to improve your set, you're running the risk of improving other player's draws. 

The rounds can end suddenly, as three dragon cards get seeded in the bottom half of the deck. This can often create some frustration as players might have been lining up a great move right before the round suddenly ends, and they're forced to discard their hands. It's an interesting tension, that I perhaps would like a lot less in a longer game, but in this format it seems fine.

The faction powers are all really interesting, and they interact with each other in compelling ways depending on the setup, as you don't see every power every game. Another compelling aspect of this game is that there's also the option to ignore the board state, and focus on getting larger sets of cards, which can score big points at the end of the round.

I don't see this game becoming a favorite, but it's a really nice light ride.

Friends will be shocked to hear that I enjoyed a game with orcs in it! But beneath the lazy pasted-on fantasy setting is a stripped-down old-school Euro with a dash of modern variable setup and special powers.

There are a number of similarities to Ticket to Ride: each turn is a simple choice to draw a card from a display or play a matching set of cards; playing a set allows you to play markers on the board which may score later, but you also score directly for the size of sets you play. But instead of route-building, the board-play is pure area majority, and to add a counter to a region, the set of cards you play must be larger than the number of counters you already have there.

So far so simple, and the turns move pleasantly briskly (in fact the biggest problem was players not realising it was their turn again already!). But there are a couple of twists. At the beginning of the game, 6 races (this is where the bloody orcs come in) are randomly chosen from 12. When you play a set of cards, you also choose one of them to be the leader and get to execute the special power of the associated race. Some give extra scoring opportunities; some get round the restrictions on adding counters to the board; and some help you mitigate the other big twist...

Unlike Ticket to Ride, there's a hand limit and when you play a set, you have to discard the rest of your hand into the face-up display for the other players to pick over - in fact, this is the only way the display gets replenished. This helps with the briskness because you can only really focus on one objective at a time, but it also generates the biggest complaint about the game. Often the display will be empty and the players are reduced to drawing blind, hoping to add to a set. 

Opinions on the game in our group were divided and I suspect this was correlated to the amount of luck in drawing the right cards from the deck. Time will tell if it was due only to my good fortune, but it was a good first impression for me.

What a cool, quick, streamlined area-majorities / card drafting / set collection kinda game! The rules are quite simple but game play is still interesting. The powers vary widely (meld another set before discarding, hold onto some cards, place in any region, count as a bigger set, etc.) and with so many races in the box (and surely more coming soon?), you'll play a different combination every time!

[b]--- Summary ---[/b]
Players start with a hand of cards, each of which belongs to one of the races and has one of 6 colors (corresponding to the 6 regions of the board). There's also a random display of 5(?) cards at the start. On your turn, you either draw a card or play card(s).
- Draw = take a card from Display or deck, add it to your hand. If you draw a Dragon (3 were shuffled into bottom half of deck), discard it and replace unless it was the 3rd Dragon = end of Era (immediately)
- Play = meld a set of cards, either all the same color or all the same race, with one card on top. The top card's power activates. Then, if the size of the set exceeds the number of your tokens in the top card's board region (matching color), you may place another token there. Then, add the rest of your hand to the Display!

When the Era ends, score each region (chits worth 0-10 VP were randomly distributed during setup; values increase with each Era) according to area majority: award VP for 1st place in Era 1, 1st/2nd in Era 2, 1st/2nd/3rd in Era 3. Also earn VP for your sets of 2+ cards. Then shuffle all the cards and repeat. After 3 Eras, most VP wins!

Good, quick playing game with a lot of depth and replayability.A set-collection game with an area control component. The map suggest a heavier empasis on the area control as it basically has, as point scoring is a little tilted towards the sets. But both areas require a decent presence to actually grab a win. Add in bonus conditions as a side-track giving extra free board presence plus a minor account of VPs, and a side board giving an extra set to complete over the course of the game and the result is a game with a lot of choices.The variable setup adds replayability, as only a subset of card powers will be present each game. Deciding what set to collect, when to cash in on any given set in hand (forcing you to discard any excess towards a publicly available pool for your adversaries), and deciding which card will be using its ability means a lot of meaningful choices without getting swamped in them. The variable end of each round means you can get hosed if it comes quicker as expected (meaning the round order is deciding whether you cab cash in your last set), but that also results in a spike in tension keeping the tension arc fluctuating.The game has some drawbacks as well. First, the theme is clearly a paste-on. The map is a copy of Slovakia (why?). The gamebox is a thematic mismatch: it promises war and mayhem, where the 'conflict' is more along the lines of El Grande. But the biggest drawback is the big luck of the draw. If you draw a perfect set, you're golden. If you draw all different, basically you are both wasting turns as setting your adversaries up for even bigger sets. Keeping what you have is only a very limited option, as you don't have much knowledge about the hands of your adversaries. This is a big thing, as Ethnos is a strategic game at hearth, and in those games a big luck factor has too much impact on your plans.That being said, this is an excellent game: enjoyable, engaging, very playable and not too lengthy, with meaningful choices along the way. As someone that generally dislikes set-collection games, this game is highly recommended, especially for those that like this mechanic!

Ethnos is a mix between [thing=9209][/thing] and Rummy.  You collect cards and play sets (bands) of matching colors or races to play in front of you.  By playing a set, you score points based on the set size and get to place a piece on one of the six regions.  At the end of each round, points are awarded for majority of the regions.  So, this all feels similar to TTR in that you are collecting sets, scoring points for big sets, and placing pieces on the board competing for limited real estate against your opponents.

There are two good things going for the game.  First is that when you play a set of cards, you have to discard your remaining cards to the market.  So, unlike TTR, you don't accumulate like 30 cards in hand before you start playing sets.  It also makes it painful to keep drawing cards trying to find that last one you want.  Secondly, each race has a unique power and the available races is randomized each game.  This gives a little more decision space to work with.

Ultimately, it felt like I was playing a slightly-more-gamer-y version of TTR.  I'm not sure I really need another family-style lightweight game like this, but it's certainly inoffensive and could be a good filler plus at the beginning or end of the night.

Typically I like my games as complicated as you can make them, but there are always exceptions. Ethos is so straightforward you could almost categorize it as a Rule Breaking mechanic game... Basically you have a short and simple set of rules about determining area controls across a three round game. The excitement comes in with the fact you have 12 races (sets of card faces) of which you will randomly take 6, and each race has a single effect and each set of cards (band) you put down will borrow the effects of its top and area targeting card (leader). This takes a game otherwise all about band size and control degrees and complicates it by adding "cheat" effects bypassing normal rules, granting or advancing features of your plays, or providing new sources of victory points to compete over. Strategy is absolutely key, but there is no simple,pattern of "winning strategy" anyone can doggedly abuse... The relation between elements is simple, their constant flux is not. Playing well relies on being adaptive... Reacting to what other players do, choosing your battles to avoid conflicts more brutal than they're worth or to sweep in and edge out a foe, strike while the iron is hot when opportunities arise, prioritize pressing luck for a drastic play or counting on small victories to add up, and most of all, while RNG doesn't actively ruin or overly bless a player normally, making the best of the cards dumped into the communal drafting area and randomly dealt from the deck (and knowing when to do which!) all favor a player willing to roll with lunches and alter their strategy from one turn to another... Talents that rarely will one player in a circle have a monopoly on.

Aside from a varied play experience that rewards smart plays but should rarely preclude or guarentee any player in victory; the greatest virtue of Ethnos is how fast it is. Simple to learn and tach, minimal setup and tear down, turns are lightning fast (pull a card and pass turn more often than not), which makes for a game that can fit a match into small time window and wont clash with players who struggle waiting for their turn in games where turns are long, or who struggle with long games. Meanwhile, the box, board, cards, and pieces are all really nicely done, smooth, attractive, good art. The box interior was another thing I really appreciated... It's designed with shaped grooves for every one of the fair amount of extraneous pieces... Each has a place and it's obvious where it is, and they all slide in securely and space efficiently. It's gloriously well organized, honestly.... I normally use baggies to sort and consolidate games into smaller and more orderly parcels than the box... Ethnic is one of few exception where it's exemption isn't based on the box being to packed... Instead, it's just so wel organize and aesthetic as is, it feels foolish to repackage.

Honestly, I feel like I can hardly reccomend this game enough. It may lack the sharp complexity of games like Scythe or Valeria Card Kingdoms, but it's just so good at what it does, I adore it.... More similar to Hero Realms in its virtue: brilliant out of the box, gets you down to enjoying it quickly, basic variety keeps it fresh, victory is fair but not rigid, and like the comparison, easy on the wallet... Copies are going for 40 retail and you may manage to shave off ten bucks or so if you use discount sources. It's a great approachable game for everyone... The elves and wizards and skeletons may turn off the really stiff relatives who won't touch anything nerdier than Catan, but it's honestly so simple and straightforward I'd think no dedicated board game player would be turned off.

The game plays almost identically to Royals (slowly draw cards, then play sets of cards to place markers in various areas on the map). However, I felt like Royals was lacking something to push it beyond mediocre, and I think Ethnos adds the perfect element.

Ethnos adds a mechanic similar to Guildhall where each suit of cards has a unique ability and the ability is often stronger if you play more of those cards. This addition takes the barebones experience of Royals and adds combos, strategy, and more to think about. Also, you play with a different combination of cards each time so the experience will be quite a bit different from game to game.

I will say that there may be a fair amount of luck, which was also prevalent in Royals. You often end up drawing blindly from the deck and if you happen to get cards that match then you'll be in a better position. Sometimes you draw several times and none of the cards match color or type. I imagine the luck should even out over the course of the game, though.

Overall lots of fun. The ability to play from 3-6 players is nice and I imagine the game would work equally well with 4-6 (with three players you have to play a variant).

Update: After more plays the game is still great. I've seen people consider this a new gateway game and I can definitely see that. There's still a decent amount of luck of the draw but so far not enough to hinder the experience.

I also need to mention the player count. The game plays surprisingly well with three players, despite area control usually needing more players. More importantly, though, I've seen a number of reviewers talk about how perfectly this game scales at [b]all[/b] player counts and that is just wrong.

The two player game is bad. Sure, we all know that area control games don't work with two players, but it just needs to be restated here. I played a two player game just to show a friend how the game works and we aborted the game after the first age because it was so bad and there was nothing fun or interesting about the experience. The game already has a lot of luck, but with two players it comes down to pure luck. If you draw the right cards to take over the valuable areas and carry out some combos, you will win. With more players you have people discarding cards to the face-up draw row at different intervals, so timing is crucial as you try to wait out your opponents to see if they discard a card you've been waiting on. With two players you draw and discard at about the same pace so it just doesn't work.

Ethnos is an area control game that's card based.  There are six regions.  At the beginning of the game the value of each region for each of the rounds is randomly determines by assigning VP tiles to each region.  The deck of cards has six colors (matching the regions) and six races (each with a special power).

On your turn you draw a card or play a "band".  A band is either a set of cards all of a color, or all of a race.  The purpose of playing a band is to put a disc in the region of the color that is the top card in your band (the leader).  Your band must have cards in excess of the number of discs you currently have in that region.  Additionally you do the special power of the band's leader's race.  When you play a band, any cards that aren't played to the band are put face up into a common area from which players may draw cards.  You can choose any cards in the common tableau or from the face down deck.  There are dragons randomly seeded in the bottom of the deck and when you find them all the round ends immediately.  

At the end of a round, all the regions are scored.  In the first round, only the first VP chit in each region is scored.  The player with the most discs in an area gets those points. Discs stay in regions from round to round.  In the second round the first and second place chits are scored and given respectively to the players with the most and second most discs.  And all three score in the third round, going to 1st, 2nd and 3rd most discs.

Additionally, you get points for the length of your bands that you've played.  A single card is worth zero points but 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 cards are worth 1, 3, 6, 10, 15 points.  

The races change up the rules of how things work in interesting ways.  there's a good bit to think about.  There's some randomness with cards, which is okay.  Other players may inadvertently mess you up.   But overall I liked this game a lot.

[thing=206718][/thing] is an area control mixed with hand management. [thing=206718][/thing] has a high variety as not all races enter every game, thus often you get new and interesting interactions between the powers of them.

The mechanics are simple: on each turn, the person either plays a set of cards or draw a card - from the opens one (if any) or from the draw deck. Furthermore, depending on the "leader" chosen for the set, some special effect takes place: for instance, the Centaurs allow playing a second set of cards; the Elfs allow the player to hold cards in hand; the Dwarfs make the set be worth more at the end of the round; etc. Also the leader, by its color, gives the region on the board in which a control marker will be placed. The first marker needs a set of only one card; the second marker in the same region, requires at least a set of two; the third, at least three; and so on; making increasingly harder to sustain control of a region.

After playing a set, the player discard all the remaining cards still in hand to the open draw area, meaning the others (and even the person himself) will the able to draw them.

[thing=206718][/thing] is a well made and very functional game. Its turns are fast, and one play will clock around 1 hour. The level of interaction is high, with disputes for the regions as well as for the available open cards; but is worth mentioning that it isn't a destructive interaction: once a marker is placed, it stays there. Luck is present, and not in a small amount - it can even the decisive, specially due to some races that made discard less often and smaller, meaning more blind draws; yet, the luck didn't bothered us. The artwork by the great John Howe is awesome.

Good game. I watched a few reviews before buying the game. But the game deserves its reputation. The mechanics are quite simple, but there is much going on. The game should play quickly once everyone understands what they are doing. Sometimes, it is your turn before you even know it, so there is little down time. The game is about area control and card set collection. You collect sets to control the areas based on the color of the card or the type of creature on the card. When and how to develop the card sets is a part of the riddle. It is interesting how points are distributed through the three rounds. The first round is the longest and the second and third rounds are much shorter because you need more cards in order to place more influence on the board. As a result, the deck which acts as the time clock runs out much more quickly. How the points are distributed on the board, will influence where you play your cards and what type of sets you are trying to collect. The card you lead with has special powers. Knowing the special powers requires a little memorization although the basic information is on the card. The need to memorize actions leads to my only issue with the game. They should have cardboard aids for the specific powers of each type of creature in the game. When I have played with new players, more than once players who are unfamiliar with the game need to go through the rules for a full explanation of the creatures powers. This is a minor issue, but it would have been a nice touch to have. It is also true that just about any theme could be put on this game. If the magical lore turns someone who you might play with off, then I would advise against this game. The magical lore does not bother me and is a justification for the powers on the cards. It is the land of Ethnos and there is a clear theme that fits well with this game. I do see room for expanding this game by adding new cards, a new map, and possibly and/or new ways to score. However, expansions would depend on the success of this game.

Pretty basic area control with a very unique card driven placement mechanism.  The cards you draw are largely random, but whenever you lay a set any left over cards go into a TTR-esque drawing line so there is certainly some luck mitigation to be had. The variable region scoring and large number of special power cards should add some nice extra replayability to Ethnos too.
